OVERVIEW: The Pyramid series consists of shallow, well drained soils formed in volcanic ash overlying ash influenced colluvium on mountain sideslopes.  Slopes range from 12 to 60 percent.  Mean annual temperature is about 40 degrees F., and the average annual precipitation is about 60 inches.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Medial, amorphic Lithic Vitricryands

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Pyramid loamy fine sand -- under native grass  (All colors are for moist soil)
Oi--0 to 2 inches; litter, mostly straw.  (2 to 4 inches thick)
Oe--2 to 4 inches; very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) mat of partially decomposed leaves; many roots; very strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (1 to 2 inches thick)
C--4 to 8 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) loamy fine sand volcanic ash; single grained; loose; mottled with dark brown, especially at bottom of horizon; few roots; very strongly to strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (3 to 6 inches thick)
Ab--8 to 15 inches; dark reddish brown (5YR 3/2) cobbly silt loam; weak fine granular structure; friable; common roots; extremely acid; clear wavy boundary.  (4 to 7 inches thick)
ACb--15 to 25 inches; dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) very cobbly silt loam grading into weathered parent rock; very strongly acid.  (6 to 15 inches thick)
R--25 inches; consolidated bedrock

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Northeastern Kodiak Island Area, Alaska.  Ridge west of Pasagshak Bay Road, 5.1 miles south of junction with Chiniak Cape Road.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content: RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Thickness of the layer of recent volcanic ash ranges from 2 to 9 inches, but is usually 4 to 6 inches thick.  The texture of the ash ranges from silt loam to loamy fine sand.  Depth to bedrock ranges from 10 to 20 inches.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There are no known competing series.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Pyramid soils are on steep ridges and mountainslopes.  The soils are formed in a mixture of volcanic ash and residuum/colluvium from metamorphic and igneous rocks.  The climate is cool maritime.  Average annual precipitation ranges from 50 to 70 inches, and the average annual temperature is about 40 degrees F.  Temperatures below freezing are recorded on fewer than 40 days annually, and temperatures above 70 degrees F. are rare.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained.  Moderate Permeability. Runoff is rapid.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  On slopes of less than 45 percent, the soils are used as rangeland.  The native vegetation is tall grass, dominantly bluejoint reedgrass, and associated plants including fireweed, salmonberry, and alder.  A few patches of white spruce, Sitka spruce, and paper birch occur in places.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern Kodiak Island, Alaska, and adjacent islands.  The series is extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Portland, Oregon

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Northeastern Kodiak Island Area, Alaska, 1959.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  The concept of the Pyramid series is poorly defined, especially in regards to the properties of the underlying material.  The typical profile should classify as thixotropic-skeletal.  More data is needed to define the central concept or the series should be inactivated (jpm, 4/87). More data on this soil will be collected when the survey is updated.
Source of the volcanic ash is the 1912 eruption of Mt. Novarupta and Mt.  Katmai on the Alaska Peninsula.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
